body:
Heroku can get bent, but to be honest, I've never noticed any issues with speed before.

Can't say the same now, but its not enough for me to care, and I know they're still ironing some things out. Makes me wonder if its a location thing, or a "we're still ironing some things out" thing.

body: It is a bit more complicated than a bunch of networked computers, generally the servers are designed to handle traffic loads and instances of events.   A good server can handle 50,000 events at a time, and run $100's of thousands.   On top of that there is the bandwidth issues.   How much bandwidth does this site need?  How much does it cost, and how do you get that to the facility that you're hosting the servers in.
body_html: It is a bit more complicated than a bunch of networked computers, generally the servers are designed to handle traffic loads and instances of events. A good server can handle 50,000 events at a time, and run $100's of thousands. On top of that there is the bandwidth issues. How much bandwidth does this site need? How much does it cost, and how do you get that to the facility that you're hosting the servers in.

post.title: Is it just me or is ruqqus actually faster now?

body:
Saying that a server alone would cost hundreds of thousands might be a little bit of a stretch, not cheap, sure. We kinda did this thought exercise the other night, during the outage. If you consider Ruqqus to only be ruqqus.com, and not i.ruqqus.com or api.ruqqus.com, and assuming the same infrastructure setup we'd have here, the estimation is as follows:

* 3x Server Nodes, Dual Intel Xeon Silver @ 16c/32t, 128GB RAM, 10Gb LAN + 2x1Gb LAN + 100Mbps IPMI
* 2x Distributed Storage Shelf, 12TB each, 3TB Usable (RAID 0+1 or similar ZFS configuration, but DAS would require proper RAID)
* 1x Enterprise NAS 12TB, 6 Usable (RAID 1 or ZFS Equivalent), 4x 1GB LAN in 2x2 LACP configuration
* 1x Enterprise Firewall (Palo Alto, Cisco, F5, etc)
* 40Gbps TOR switching

This would be used to run:

* 1 Load Balancer
* 2 Reverse Proxy
* 3-5 front-end servers
* 3-5 Back-end application servers
* 2 Leader SQL
* 2 Follower SQL
* Backup Services
* SEIM/Performance Monitoring
* Orchestration server


Hardware costs alone to do it properly are about $120-140,000 USD

Then there's the problem of finding a Colocation facility, or somewhere that will allow multiple enterprise class internet connections at at least LAG 3x1Gbps connection. Those are about $400/mo per connection per ISP, so with a active-active 2x2 that's $1600/mo. Plus average half-rack rentals of $400/mo or so in the USA.

Then there's software licensing. Let's be honest, KVM isn't performant enough. And you'll want support for this. VMWare ESXi with VMotion and VROP is going to run $10,500/yr. Then a Backup Solution, but I'll digress that backing up core data with Restic or another scripting type backup service would "work", but TTE would be terrible.

Then you have the worry of maintenance. Hardware fails. So you'll need a third party remote-hands or be able to give up hours and hours of your life and some training to actually rack and configure all of this properly. My hourly rate was about $225/hr when I was doing this, and this would be a 45-60 hour project, all things considered, and then a flat $175/mo and some fees for onsite service. 


-----------------------------------------

Now, can you technically run this site with a podunk used server off eBay and some sweet talking Comcast? Probably, until your connection is saturated and your home or even SOHO router can't take it and craps out. There goes downtime. Then there's backups. How/where you storing them? Bet you with the volume of SQL data, your default 1Gbps x 1 LAN isn't working fast enough to move the bits around, causing performance issues. Updates? Downtime. The above setup is what I'd call the _absolute minimum_ to run a website at scale with at least 3 9's uptime. (99.9% over a year). And again, that's provided the Colo/ISP isn't offended by anything. Want Level 1 Trunk access. You're literally talking $30,000-$50,000/mo, and even then you're dealing with either Sprint, NTT, AT&T, or CentruyLink. 

-------------------------

So basically, a proper setup would be about $200,000 to start, doing it properly, many more weeks/months of config, and ongoing costs 8-10x what the Cloud service is. There's a reason even fortune 50 companies are running with AWS/Azure. In the professional world, the Colo is dying at Small/Medium scale, and only established enterprise or Hyperscale even bothers anymore. There's tons of savings by going with a proper provider. Point is - running a site like Ruqqus on your own _can be cheap_, but _doing it right_ is a whole other matter entirely. When we have the volume of people coming here that we do, I think the admins are making a good choice with how they're choosing to provide services - partnering with a hyperscale provider that can net them significant cost savings and provide the resources at a literal fraction of the startup costs of a colocation setup. Now, is colocation or self hosting cheaper in the long run? Sure, but only after about 4-5 years, assuming 0 income generation, after which time, you're prepping for a re-stack to remain in warranty for your actual hardware.


-------------------

Anyone care to guess what my day job is?
body_html:
Saying that a server alone would cost hundreds of thousands might be a little bit of a stretch, not cheap, sure. We kinda did this thought exercise the other night, during the outage. If you consider Ruqqus to only be ruqqus.com, and not i.ruqqus.com or api.ruqqus.com, and assuming the same infrastructure setup we'd have here, the estimation is as follows:

  • 3x Server Nodes, Dual Intel Xeon Silver @ 16c/32t, 128GB RAM, 10Gb LAN + 2x1Gb LAN + 100Mbps IPMI
  • 2x Distributed Storage Shelf, 12TB each, 3TB Usable (RAID 0+1 or similar ZFS configuration, but DAS would require proper RAID)
  • 1x Enterprise NAS 12TB, 6 Usable (RAID 1 or ZFS Equivalent), 4x 1GB LAN in 2x2 LACP configuration
  • 1x Enterprise Firewall (Palo Alto, Cisco, F5, etc)
  • 40Gbps TOR switching

This would be used to run:

  • 1 Load Balancer
  • 2 Reverse Proxy
  • 3-5 front-end servers
  • 3-5 Back-end application servers
  • 2 Leader SQL
  • 2 Follower SQL
  • Backup Services
  • SEIM/Performance Monitoring
  • Orchestration server

Hardware costs alone to do it properly are about $120-140,000 USD

Then there's the problem of finding a Colocation facility, or somewhere that will allow multiple enterprise class internet connections at at least LAG 3x1Gbps connection. Those are about $400/mo per connection per ISP, so with a active-active 2x2 that's $1600/mo. Plus average half-rack rentals of $400/mo or so in the USA.

Then there's software licensing. Let's be honest, KVM isn't performant enough. And you'll want support for this. VMWare ESXi with VMotion and VROP is going to run $10,500/yr. Then a Backup Solution, but I'll digress that backing up core data with Restic or another scripting type backup service would "work", but TTE would be terrible.

Then you have the worry of maintenance. Hardware fails. So you'll need a third party remote-hands or be able to give up hours and hours of your life and some training to actually rack and configure all of this properly. My hourly rate was about $225/hr when I was doing this, and this would be a 45-60 hour project, all things considered, and then a flat $175/mo and some fees for onsite service.

Now, can you technically run this site with a podunk used server off eBay and some sweet talking Comcast? Probably, until your connection is saturated and your home or even SOHO router can't take it and craps out. There goes downtime. Then there's backups. How/where you storing them? Bet you with the volume of SQL data, your default 1Gbps x 1 LAN isn't working fast enough to move the bits around, causing performance issues. Updates? Downtime. The above setup is what I'd call the absolute minimum to run a website at scale with at least 3 9's uptime. (99.9% over a year). And again, that's provided the Colo/ISP isn't offended by anything. Want Level 1 Trunk access. You're literally talking $30,000-$50,000/mo, and even then you're dealing with either Sprint, NTT, AT&T, or CentruyLink.

So basically, a proper setup would be about $200,000 to start, doing it properly, many more weeks/months of config, and ongoing costs 8-10x what the Cloud service is. There's a reason even fortune 50 companies are running with AWS/Azure. In the professional world, the Colo is dying at Small/Medium scale, and only established enterprise or Hyperscale even bothers anymore. There's tons of savings by going with a proper provider. Point is - running a site like Ruqqus on your own can be cheap, but doing it right is a whole other matter entirely. When we have the volume of people coming here that we do, I think the admins are making a good choice with how they're choosing to provide services - partnering with a hyperscale provider that can net them significant cost savings and provide the resources at a literal fraction of the startup costs of a colocation setup. Now, is colocation or self hosting cheaper in the long run? Sure, but only after about 4-5 years, assuming 0 income generation, after which time, you're prepping for a re-stack to remain in warranty for your actual hardware.

Anyone care to guess what my day job is?

Then a Backup Solution, but I'll digress that backing up core data with Restic or another scripting type backup service would "work", but TTE would be terrible.

Then you have the worry of maintenance. Hardware fails. So you'll need a third party remote-hands or be able to give up hours and hours of your life and some training to actually rack and configure all of this properly. My hourly rate was about $225/hr when I was doing this, and this would be a 45-60 hour project, all things considered, and then a flat $175/mo and some fees for onsite service. 


-----------------------------------------

Now, can you technically run this site with a podunk used server off eBay and some sweet talking Comcast? Probably, until your connection is saturated and your home or even SOHO router can't take it and craps out. There goes downtime. Then there's backups. How/where you storing them? Bet you with the volume of SQL data, your default 1Gbps x 1 LAN isn't working fast enough to move the bits around, causing performance issues. Updates? Downtime. The above setup is what I'd call the _absolute minimum_ to run a website at scale with at least 3 9's uptime. (99.9% over a year). And again, that's provided the Colo/ISP isn't offended by anything. Want Level 1 Trunk access. You're literally talking $30,000-$50,000/mo, and even then you're dealing with either Sprint, NTT, AT&T, or CentruyLink. 

-------------------------

So basically, a proper setup would be about $200,000 to start, doing it properly, many more weeks/months of config, and ongoing costs 8-10x what the Cloud service is. There's a reason even fortune 50 companies are running with AWS/Azure. In the professional world, the Colo is dying at Small/Medium scale, and only established enterprise or Hyperscale even bothers anymore. There's tons of savings by going with a proper provider. Point is - running a site like Ruqqus on your own _can be cheap_, but _doing it right_ is a whole other matter entirely. When we have the volume of people coming here that we do, I think the admins are making a good choice with how they're choosing to provide services - partnering with a hyperscale provider that can net them significant cost savings and provide the resources at a literal fraction of the startup costs of a colocation setup. Now, is colocation or self hosting cheaper in the long run? Sure, but only after about 4-5 years, assuming 0 income generation, after which time, you're prepping for a re-stack to remain in warranty for your actual hardware.


-------------------

Anyone care to guess what my day job is?
parent.body_html:
Saying that a server alone would cost hundreds of thousands might be a little bit of a stretch, not cheap, sure. We kinda did this thought exercise the other night, during the outage. If you consider Ruqqus to only be ruqqus.com, and not i.ruqqus.com or api.ruqqus.com, and assuming the same infrastructure setup we'd have here, the estimation is as follows:

  • 3x Server Nodes, Dual Intel Xeon Silver @ 16c/32t, 128GB RAM, 10Gb LAN + 2x1Gb LAN + 100Mbps IPMI
  • 2x Distributed Storage Shelf, 12TB each, 3TB Usable (RAID 0+1 or similar ZFS configuration, but DAS would require proper RAID)
  • 1x Enterprise NAS 12TB, 6 Usable (RAID 1 or ZFS Equivalent), 4x 1GB LAN in 2x2 LACP configuration
  • 1x Enterprise Firewall (Palo Alto, Cisco, F5, etc)
  • 40Gbps TOR switching

This would be used to run:

  • 1 Load Balancer
  • 2 Reverse Proxy
  • 3-5 front-end servers
  • 3-5 Back-end application servers
  • 2 Leader SQL
  • 2 Follower SQL
  • Backup Services
  • SEIM/Performance Monitoring
  • Orchestration server

Hardware costs alone to do it properly are about $120-140,000 USD

Then there's the problem of finding a Colocation facility, or somewhere that will allow multiple enterprise class internet connections at at least LAG 3x1Gbps connection. Those are about $400/mo per connection per ISP, so with a active-active 2x2 that's $1600/mo. Plus average half-rack rentals of $400/mo or so in the USA.

Then there's software licensing. Let's be honest, KVM isn't performant enough. And you'll want support for this. VMWare ESXi with VMotion and VROP is going to run $10,500/yr. Then a Backup Solution, but I'll digress that backing up core data with Restic or another scripting type backup service would "work", but TTE would be terrible.

Then you have the worry of maintenance. Hardware fails. So you'll need a third party remote-hands or be able to give up hours and hours of your life and some training to actually rack and configure all of this properly. My hourly rate was about $225/hr when I was doing this, and this would be a 45-60 hour project, all things considered, and then a flat $175/mo and some fees for onsite service.

Now, can you technically run this site with a podunk used server off eBay and some sweet talking Comcast? Probably, until your connection is saturated and your home or even SOHO router can't take it and craps out. There goes downtime. Then there's backups. How/where you storing them? Bet you with the volume of SQL data, your default 1Gbps x 1 LAN isn't working fast enough to move the bits around, causing performance issues. Updates? Downtime. The above setup is what I'd call the absolute minimum to run a website at scale with at least 3 9's uptime. (99.9% over a year). And again, that's provided the Colo/ISP isn't offended by anything. Want Level 1 Trunk access. You're literally talking $30,000-$50,000/mo, and even then you're dealing with either Sprint, NTT, AT&T, or CentruyLink.

So basically, a proper setup would be about $200,000 to start, doing it properly, many more weeks/months of config, and ongoing costs 8-10x what the Cloud service is. There's a reason even fortune 50 companies are running with AWS/Azure. In the professional world, the Colo is dying at Small/Medium scale, and only established enterprise or Hyperscale even bothers anymore. There's tons of savings by going with a proper provider. Point is - running a site like Ruqqus on your own can be cheap, but doing it right is a whole other matter entirely. When we have the volume of people coming here that we do, I think the admins are making a good choice with how they're choosing to provide services - partnering with a hyperscale provider that can net them significant cost savings and provide the resources at a literal fraction of the startup costs of a colocation setup. Now, is colocation or self hosting cheaper in the long run? Sure, but only after about 4-5 years, assuming 0 income generation, after which time, you're prepping for a re-stack to remain in warranty for your actual hardware.

Anyone care to guess what my day job is?

post.body: I think being kicked off herouku was actually a blessing in disguise.
